sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.l: Atlas, who bears upon his brazen back the pressure of the sky, ancient dwelling of the gods, begat Maia from a daughter of one of those gods, and she bare me Hermes to mighty Zeus, to be the servant of the powers divine.

Lo! I am come to this land of Delphi where sits Phoebus on the centre of the world and giveth oracles to men, ever chanting lays prophetic of things that are to be. Now there is a city in Hellas of no small note, called after Pallas, goddess of the golden lance;

there did Phoebus force his love on Creusa, daughter of Erechtheus, beneath the rock of Pallas, northward of Athens’ steep realm, called Macrae by the kings of Attica. And she without her father’s knowledge—for such was the god’s good pleasure,—

bore the burden in her womb unto the end, and when her time came, she brought forth a child in the house and carried him away to the selfsame cave wherein the god declared his love to her, and she cradled him in the hollow of a rounded ark and cast him forth to die,

observant of the custom of her ancestors and of earth-born Erichthonius, whom the daughter of Zeus gave into the charge of the daughters of Agraulus, after setting on either side, to keep him safe, a guard of serpents twain. Hence in that land among the Erechthidae ’tis a

custom to protect their babes with charms of golden snakes. But ere she left the babe to die, the young mother tied about him her own broidered robe. And this is the request that Phoebus craves of me, for he is my brother, “Go, brother, to those children of the soil

that dwell in glorious Athens, for well thou knowest Athena’s city, and take a new-born babe from out the hollow rock, his cradle and his swaddling-clothes as well, and bear him to my prophetic shrine at Delphi, and set him at the entering-in of my temple.

What else remains shall be my care, for that child is mine, that thou mayst know it.” So I, to do my brother Loxias a service, took up the woven ark and bore it off, and at the threshold of the shrine I have laid the babe,
after opening the lid of the wicker cradle that the child might be seen.
But just as the sun-god was starting forth to run his course, a priestess chanced to enter the god’s shrine; and when her eyes lit upon the tender babe she thought it strange that any Delphian maid

should dare to cast her child of shame down at the temple of the god; wherefore her purpose was to remove him beyond the altar, but from pity she renounced her cruel thought, and the god to help his child did second her pity to save the babe from being cast out. So she took and brought him up,

but she knew not that Phoebus was his sire nor of the mother that bare him, nor yet did the child know his parents. While yet he was a child, around the altar that fed him he would ramble at his play, but when he came to man’s estate, the Delphians made him treasurer of the god

and steward of all his store, and found him true, and so until the present day he leads a holy life in the god’s temple. Meantime Creusa, mother of this youth, is wedded to Xuthus; and thus it came to pass; a war broke out 'twixt Athens and the folk of Chalcodon

who dwell in the land of Euboea; and Xuthus took part therein and helped to end it, for which he received the hand of Creusa as his guerdon,
albeit he was no native, but an Achaean, sprung from Aeolus, the son of Zeus; and after many years of wedded life

he and Creusa still are childless; wherefore they are come to this oracle of Apollo in their desire for offspring. To this end is Loxias guiding their destiny nor hath it escaped his ken, as some suppose. For when Xuthus enters this shrine,

the god will give him his own son and declare that Xuthus is the sire, that so the boy may come to his mother’s home and be acknowledged by Creusa, while the marriage of Loxias remains a secret and the child obtains his rights; and he shall cause him to be called Ion, founder of a realm in Asia,

through all the breadth of Hellas. But now will I get me to yon grotto ’neath the laurel’s shade that I may learn what is decreed about the child. For I see the son of Loxias now coming forth to cleanse the gateway in front of the temple
with boughs of laurel. I greet him first of all the gods by his name Ion which he soon shall bear.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Lo! the sun-god is e’en now turning towards the earth his chariot-car resplendent; before yon fire the stars retire

to night’s mysterious gloom from forth the firmament; the peaks of Parnassus, where no man may set foot, are all ablaze and hail the car of day for mortal’s service. Up mounts the smoke of myrrh, offering of the desert;
to Phoebus' roof; there on the holy tripod sits the Delphian priestess, chanting to the ears of Hellas in numbers loud, whate’er Apollo doth proclaim. Ye Delphians, votaries of Phoebus, away!

to Castalia’s gushing fount as silver clear, and, when ye have bathed you in its waters pure, enter the shrine; and keep your lips in holy silence that it may be well, careful to utter words of good omen amongst yourselves
to those who wish to consult the oracle; while I with laurel-sprays and sacred wreaths and drops of water sprinkled o’er the floor will purify the entrance to the shrine of Phoebus,

my task each day from childhood’s hour; and
with my bow will I put to flight the flocks of feathered fowls that harm his sacred offerings;
for here in Phoebus’ shrine, which nurtured me, I minister, an orphan, fatherless and motherless.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Come, thou tender laurel-shoot, gathered from gardens divine to wait upon the glorious god,
thou that sweepest clean the altar of Phoebus hard by his shrine, where holy founts, that ever gush with ceaseless flow,
bedew the myrtle’s hallowed spray wherewith I cleanse the temple-floor the livelong day, so soon as the swift sun-god wings his flight on high, in my daily ministration.
Hail Paean, prince of healing! blest, ah! doubly blest be thou, child of Latona!

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Fair the service that I render to thee, Phoebus, before thy house,
honouring thy seat of prophecy; a glorious task I count it, to serve not mortal man but deathless gods; wherefore I never weary
of performing holy services. Phoebus is to me as the father that begot me, for as such I praise the god that gives me food. Whom I call by that helpful name of father,
Tis Phoebus, who dwelleth in the temple, Hail Paean, healing god, good luck to thee and blessing, child of Latona!

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: My task is nearly done
of sweeping with the laurel broom, so now from a golden ewer will I sprinkle o’er the ground water from Castalia’s gushing spring, scattering the liquid dew
with hands from all defilement free. Oh may I never cease thus to serve Phoebus, or, if I do, may fortune smile upon me!
Ha! they come, the feathered tribes,
leaving their nests on Parnassus. I forbid ye to settle on the coping or enter the gilded dome. Thou herald of Zeus, that masterest the might of other birds with those talons of thine,
once more shall my arrow o’ertake thee.

Lo! another comes sailing towards the altar, a swan this
time; take thy bright plumes elsewhere; the lyre that Phoebus tuneth to thy song shall never
save thee from the bow; so fly away, and settle at the Delian mere, for if thou wilt not hearken, thy blood shall choke the utterance of thy fair melody.
Ha! what new bird comes now? Does it mean to lodge a nest of dry straw for its brood beneath the gables? Soon shall my twanging bow drive thee away. Dost not hear me?
Away and rear thy young amid the streams of swirling Alpheus, or get thee to the woody Isthmian glen, that Phoebus’ offerings and his shrine may take no hurt. I am loth to slay ye,
ye messengers to mortal man of messages from heaven; still must I serve Phoebus, to whose tasks I am devoted, nor will I cease to minister to those that give me food.

sp.speaker: (First) Chorus
sp.l: It is not in holy Athens

only that there are courts of the gods with fine colonnades, and the worship of Apollo, guardian of highways; but here, too, at the shrine of Loxias, son of Latona, shines the lovely eye of day on faces twain.

sp.speaker: (Second) Chorus
sp.l: Just look at this! here is the son of Zeus killing with his scimitar of gold the watersnake of Lerna. Do look at him, my friend!

sp.speaker: (First) Chorus
sp.l: Yes, I see. And close to him stands another
with a blazing torch uplifted; who is he? Can this be the warrior Iolaus whose story is told on my broidery, who shares with
the son of Zeus his labours and helps him in the moil?

sp.speaker: (Third) Chorus
sp.l: Oh! but look at this! a man mounted on a winged horse, killing a fire-breathing monster with three bodies.

sp.speaker: (First) Chorus
sp.l: I am turning my eyes in every direction. Behold the rout of the giants carved on these walls of stone.

sp.speaker: (Fourth) Chorus
sp.l: Yes, yes, good friends, I am looking.

sp.speaker: (Fifth) Chorus
sp.l: Dost see her standing over Enceladus brandishing her shield with the Gorgon’s head?

sp.speaker: (Sixth) Chorus
sp.l: I see Pallas, my own goddess.

sp.speaker: (Seventh) Chorus
sp.l: Again, dost see the massy thunderbolt all aflame in the far-darting hands of Zeus?

sp.speaker: (Eighth) Chorus
sp.l: I do; ’tis blasting with its flame Mimas, that deadly foe.

sp.speaker: (Ninth) Chorus
sp.l: Bromius too, the god of revelry, is slaying another of the sons of Earth with his thyrsus of ivy, never meant for battle.

sp.speaker: (First) Chorus
sp.l: Thou that art stationed by this fane, to thee I do address me,
may we pass the threshold of these vaults, with our fair white feet?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Nay, ye must not, stranger ladies.

sp.speaker: (Tenth) Chorus
sp.l: May I ask thee about something I have heard?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What wouldst thou ask?

sp.speaker: (Eleventh) Chorus
sp.l: Is it really true that the temple of Phoebus stands upon the centre of the world?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: στέμμασί γʼ ἐνδυτόν, ἀμφὶ δὲ Γοργόνες.

sp.speaker: (Twelfth) Chorus
sp.l: οὕτω καὶ φάτις αὐδᾷ.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: If ye have offered a sacrificial cake before the shrine and have aught ye wish to ask Phoebus, approach the altar; but enter not the inmost sanctuary, save ye have sacrificed sheep.

sp.speaker: (Thirteenth) Chorus
sp.l: I understand; but we have ho mind to trespass against the god’s law; the pictures here without will amuse us.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Feast your eyes on all ye may.

sp.speaker: (Fourteenth) Chorus
sp.l: My mistress gave me leave to see these vaulted chambers.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Whose handmaids do ye avow yourselves?

sp.speaker: (Fifteenth) Chorus
sp.l: The temple, where Pallas dwells, is the nursing-home of my lords. But lo! here is she of whom thou askest.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Lady, whosoe’er thou art, I see thou art of noble birth, and thy bearing proves thy gentle breeding. For from his bearing one may mostly judge

whether a man is nobly born. Yet am I much amazed to see thee close thine eyes in grief and with tears bedew thy noble face, when thou standest face to face with the holy oracle of Loxias. Why, lady, art thou thus disquieted?
Here, where all others show their joy at sight of Phoebus’ sanctuary, thine eye is wet with tears.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Most courteously, sir stranger, dost thou express surprise at these my tears; the sight of this temple of Apollo

recalled to me a memory of long ago, and somehow my thoughts went wandering home, though I am here myself. Ah, hapless race of women! ah, ye reckless gods! What shall I say? to what standard shall we refer justice if through the injustice of our lords and masters we are brought to ruin?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Why, lady, art thou thus cast down, past all finding out?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: ’Tis naught; I have shot my bolt; for what remains, I say no more, nor seek thou further to inquire.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Who art thou and whence? who is the father that begat thee? by what name are we to call thee?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Creusa is my name, the daughter of Erechtheus I; my native land is Athens.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: A glorious city thine, lady, a noble line of ancestry! with what reverence I behold thee!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Thus far, no further goes my luck, good sir.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Pray, is the current legend true—

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What is thy question? I fain would learn.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Was thy father’s grandsire really sprung from Earth?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yes, Erichthonius was; but my high birth avails me not

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Is it true Athena reared him from the ground?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Aye, and into maidens’ hands, though not his mother’s—

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Consigned him, did she? as ’tis wont to be set forth in painting.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yes, to the daughters of Cecrops, to keep him safe unseen.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: I have heard the maidens opened the ark wherein the goddess laid him.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: And so they died, dabbling with their blood the rocky cliff.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Even so. But what of this next story? Is it true or groundless?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What is thy question? Ask on, I have no calls upon my leisure.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Did thy sire Erechtheus offer thy sisters as a sacrifice?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: For his country’s sake he did endure to slay the maids as victims.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: And how didst thou, alone of al thy sisters, escape?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I was still a tender babe in my mother’s arms.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Did the earth really open its mouth and swallow thy father?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: The sea-god smote and slew him with his trident.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Is there a spot there called Macrae?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Why ask that? what memories thou recallest!

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Doth the Pythian god with his flashing fire do honour to the place?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Honour, yes! Honour, indeed! would I had never seen the spot!

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How now? dost thou abhor that which the god holds dear?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: No, no; but I and that cave are witnesses of a deed of shame.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Lady, who is the Athenian lord that calls thee wife?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: No citizen of Athens, but a stranger from another land.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Who is he? he must have been one of noble birth.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Xuthus, son of Aeolus, sprung from Zeus.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: And how did he, a stranger, win thee a native born?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Hard by Athens lies a neighbouring township, Euboea.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: With a bounding line of waters in between, so I have heard.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: This did he sack, making common cause with Cecrops’ sons.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Coming as an ally, maybe; he won thy hand for this?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yes, this was his dower of battle, the prize of his prowess.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Art thou come to the oracle alone, or with thy lord?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: With him. But he is now visiting the cavern of Trophonius.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: As a spectator merely, or to consult the oracle?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: ’Tis his wish to hear the self-same answer from Trophonius and Phoebus too.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Is it to seek earth’s produce or fruit of offspring that ye come?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: We are childless, though wedded these many years.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hast thou never been a mother? art thou wholly childless?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Phoebus knows whether I am childless.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Unhappy wife! how this doth mar thy fortune else so happy!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: But who art thou? how blest I count thy mother!

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Lady, I am called the servant of Apollo, and so I am.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: An offering of thy city, or sold to him by some master?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Naught know I but this, that I am called the slave of Loxias.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Then do i in my turn pity thee, sir stranger.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Because I know not her that bare me, or him that begat me.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Is thy home here in the temple, or hast thou a house to dwell in?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: The god’s whole temple is my house, wherever sleep o’ertakes me.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Was it as a child or young man that thou earnest to the temple?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Those who seem to know the truth, say I was but a babe.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What Delphian maid, then, weaned thee?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: I never knew a mother’s breast. But she who brought me up—

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Who was she, unhappy youth? I see thy sufferings in my own.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: The priestess of Phoebus; I look oh her as my mother.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Until thou earnest unto man’s estate, what nurture hadst thou?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: The altar fed me, and the bounty of each casual guest.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Woe is thy mother, then, whoe’er she was!

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Maybe my birth was some poor woman’s wrong.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Hast thou any store, for thy dress is costly enough?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: The god I serve gives me these robes to wear.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Wert thou never eager to inquire into thy birth?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Ah! yes, lady! but I have no clue at all to guide me.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Alas! I know another woman who hath suffered as thy mother did.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Who is she? If she would but help me in the task, how happy should I be!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: ’Tis she on whose account I have preceded my husband hither.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What are thy wishes? be sure I will serve thee, lady.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I would fain obtain a secret answer from Apollo’s oracle.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Name it, then; the rest will I undertake for thee.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Hear, then, this story. Yet am I ashamed.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Thus wilt thou accomplish naught, for shame is a goddess slow to act.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: A friend of mine asserts that Phoebus lay with her.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Phoebus with a mortal woman? Stranger lady, say not so.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yea, and she bare the god a child without her father’s knowledge.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: It cannot be; some man did wrong her, and she is ashamed of it.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: This she denieis herself; and she hath suffered further woe.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How so, if she was wedded to a god?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: The babe she bare she did expose.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Where is the child who was thus cast forth? is he yet alive?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: No man knoweth. That is the very thing I would ask the oracle.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: But if he be no more, how did he perish?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: She supposes that beasts devoured the hapless babe.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What proof led her to form this opinion?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: She came to the place where she exposed him, but found him no longer there.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Were any drops of blood upon the path?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: None, she says; and yet she ranged the ground to and fro.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How long is it since the babe was destroyed?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Thy age and his would measure out the self-same span, were he alive.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hath she given birth to no other child since then?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: The god doth wrong her, and wretched is she in having no child.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: But what if Phoebus privily removed her child, and is rearing it?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Then is he acting unfairly in keeping to himself alone a joy he ought to share.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Ah me! this misfortune sounds so like my own.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Thee too, fair sir, thy poor mother misses, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Oh! call me not back to piteous thoughts I had forgotten.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I am dumb; proceed with that which touches my inquiry.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Dost know the one weak point in this thy story?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: ’Tis all weak in that poor lady’s case.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How should the god declare that which he wishes hidden?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: He must, if here upon the tripod he sits for all Hellas to seek to.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: He is ashamed of the deed; do not question him.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Aye, but his victim has her sorrows too.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: There is none who will act as thy medium in this.
For were Phoebus in his own temple proved a villain, he would justly wreak his vengeance on the man who expounded to thee his oracles; desist then, lady; we must not prophesy against the god’s will,

for it would be the height of folly in us, were we to try and make the gods against their will declare reluctant truths either by sacrifice of sheep at their altars, or by omens from birds. For those answers we strive to extort from heaven, lady, are goods that bring no blessing on our getting;
but what they freely offer, thereby we profit.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Many are the chances that befall the many tribes of men, and diverse are their forms. But scarce one happy scene canst thou find in all the life of man.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah! Phoebus, here as there, art thou unjust

to that absent sufferer, whose cause I now am pleading. Thou didst not preserve thy child, as in duty bound, nor wilt thou, for all thy prophetic skill, answer his mother’s questioning, that, if he be no more, a mound may be raised o’er him, or, if he live, he may some day be restored to his mother’s eyes.
In vain is this the home of oracles if the god prevents me from learning what I wish to ask. But lo! I see my noble lord, Xuthus, nigh at hand, returning 278 from the lair of Trophonius; say nothing,

sir, to my husband of what I have told thee, lest I incur reproach for troubling about secrets, and the matter take a different turn to that which I sought to give it. For women stand towards men in a difficult position, and the virtuous from being mingled with the wicked amongst us are hated;
such is our unhappy destiny.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: First to the god all hail! for he must receive the first-fruits of my salutation, and next all hail to thee, my wife! Has my delay in arriving caused thee alarm?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: By no means; but thou art come at an anxious time.
Tell me what response thou bringest from Trophonius, touching our future hopes of mutual offspring.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: He deigned not to forestal the prophecies of Phoebus. This only did he say, that neither thou nor I should return unto our house childless from the shrine.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Majestic mother of Phoebus, to our journey grant success, and may our previous dealings with thy son now find a better issue!

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: It will be so; but who acts as the god’s spokesman here?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: I serve outside the shrine, others within,
who stand near the tripod, even the noblest of the Delphians chosen by lot, sir stranger.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: ’Tis well; I have attained the utmost of my wishes. I will go within; for I am told that a victim has been slain in public before the temple for strangers,

and to-day,—for it is a lucky day,—I would fain receive the god’s oracle. Do thou, my wife, take branches of laurel, and seated at the altars pray to the gods that I may carry home from Apollo’s shrine an answer that bodeth well for offspring.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l:
All this shall be. Now, at any rate, if Loxias would retrieve his former sins, e’en though he cannot be my friend
entirely, yet will I accept whate’er he deigns to give, because he is a god.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Why doth this stranger lady hint dark reproaches against the god

unceasingly, either out of affection for her on whose behalf she seeks the oracle, or maybe because she is hiding something needing secrecy? Yet what have I to do with the daughter of Erectheus? She is naught to me.

No, I will go to the laver, and from golden ewers sprinkle the holy water. Yet must I warn Phoebus of what is happening to him; he ravishes a maid and proves unfaithful to her, and after secretly begetting a son leaves him to die. O! Phoebus, do not so, but as thou art supreme,

follow in virtue’s track; for whosoever of mortal men transgresses, him the gods punish. How, then, can it be just that you should enact your laws for men, and yourselves incur the charge of breaking them? Now I will put this case, though it will never happen.

Wert thou, wert Poseidon, and Zeus, the lord of heaven, to make atonement to mankind for every act of lawless love, ye would empty your temples in paying the fines for your misdeeds. For when ye pursue pleasure in preference to the claims of prudence, ye act unjustly; no longer is it fair
to call men wicked, if we are imitating the evil deeds of gods, but rather those who give us such examples. [Exit Ion

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: On thee I call, Athena mine, at whose birth-throes no kindly goddess lent her aid,
delivered as thou wert by Titan Prometheus from the forehead of Zeus. Come, O lady Victory, come to the Pythian shrine, winging thy way from the gilded chambers of Olympus
to the city’s streets, where Phoebus at his altar on the centre of the world brings his oracles to pass beside the dance-encircled tripod;
come, too, thou daughter of Latona, together come, ye virgin goddesses, fair sisters of Phoebus! And be this your prayer, fair maidens, that the ancient house of Erechtheus

may obtain
by clear oracles the blessing of children, though late it come.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: For this brings to man a settled source of all-surpassing bliss,
even to such as see in their ancestral halls a splendid race of strong young parents blest with offspring, to inherit from their sires
their wealth in due succession after other children; yea, for they are a defence in time of trouble, and add a charm to weal, affording to their fatherland a saving help in battle.
Give me before the pomp of wealth or royal marriages the careful nurture of noble children. The childless life I do abhor, and him who thinks it good I blame;
to a happy life amongst my children, blest with moderate wealth, may I hold fast.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ye haunts of Pan, and rocks hard by the grots of Macrae,
where Agraulos’ daughters three trip it lightly o’er the green grass-lawns before the shrine of Pallas, to the music of the piper’s varied note,
what time thou, Pan, art piping in those caves of thine, where a maiden once that had a child by Phoebus, unhappy mother! exposed her babe, forced issue of her woful wooing,
for birds to tear and beasts to rend, a bloody banquet! Never have I seen it told in woven tale or legend that children born to gods by daughters of earth have any share in bliss.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Attendant maids, that watch and wait your mistress here at the steps of the temple fragrant with incense, say, hath Xuthus already left the holy tripod and the sanctuary, or doth he still abide within to ask yet further of his childlessness?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: He is still in the temple, sir, nor hath he passed this threshold yet.
But hark! I hear a footstep at the outlet of the door, and lo! thou mayst see my master this moment coming out.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: All hail! my son; that word suits well as my first greeting to thee.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: ’Tis well with me; do but restrain thyself, and then both of us will be happy.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Give me thy hand to grasp, thy body to embrace.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Art thou in thy senses, sir, or hath some spiteful god reft thee of them?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I am in my senses, for I have found what I hold most dear, and am eager to show my love.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Cease! touch me not, nor tear these garlands of the god!

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I will embrace thee, for I am not seizing what is not my own, but only finding my own that I love full well.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hands off! or thou shalt feel an arrow pierce thy ribs.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Why dost thou shun me, now that thou findest in me thy nearest and dearest?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: I am not fond of schooling boors and crazy strangers.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Kill me, burn me, if thou wilt; for, if thou dost, thou wilt be thy father’s murderer.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Thou my father, indeed i Oh! is not news like this enough to make me laugh?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Not so; my tale, as it proceeds, will prove to thee what I assert.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Pray, what hast thou to tell me?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: That I am thy own father, and thou my very child.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Who says so?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Loxias, who gave thee nurture, though thou wert my son.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Thou art thy own witness.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Nay, I have learnt the answer of the god.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Thou art mistaken in the dark riddle thou hast heard.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: It seems then I do not hear aright.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What said Phoebus?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: That the man who met me—

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: When and where?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: As I came forth from the god’s temple—

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Well! what should happen to him?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Should be my own true son.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Thy own true son, or a gift from others?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: A gift, but mine for all that.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Am I the first that thou didst meet?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I have met no other, my son.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Whence came this piece of luck?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: To both of us alike it causes surprise.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Ah I but who was my mother?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Did not Phoebus tell thee that?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I was so pleased with this, I did not ask him that.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: I must have sprung from mother earth.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: The ground brings forth no children.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How can I be thine?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I know not; I refer it to the god.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Come, let us try another theme.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Better hold to this, my son.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Didst thou e’er indulge in illicit amours?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Yes, in the folly of youth.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Ere thou didst win Erechtheus’ daughter?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Never since.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Could it be, then, thou didst beget me?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: The time coincides therewith.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: In that case, how came I hither?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: That puzzles me.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: After that long journey too?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: That, too, perplexes me.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Didst thou in days gone by come to the Pythian rock?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Yes, to join in the mystic rites of Bacchus.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Didst thou lodge with one of the public hosts?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: With one who at Delphi—

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Initiated thee? or what is it thou sayest?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Among the frantic votaries of Bacchus.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Wert thou sober, or in thy cups?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: I had indulged in the pleasures of the wine-cup.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: That is just the history of my birth.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Fate hath discovered thee, my son.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How came I to the temple?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Maybe the maid exposed thee.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: I have escaped the shame of slavish birth.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Acknowledge then thy father, my son.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: It is not right that I should mistrust the god.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Thou art right there.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What more can I desire—

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Thine eyes now open to the sights they should.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Than from a son of Zeus to spring?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Which is indeed thy lot.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: May I embrace the author of my being?

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Aye, put thy trust in the god.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hail to thee, father mine.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: With joy that title I accept.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: This day—

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Hath made me blest.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Ah, mother dear! shall I ever see thee too? Now more than ever do I long to gaze upon thee, whoe’er thou art.
But thou perhaps art dead, and I shall never have the chance.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: We share the good luck of thy house; but still I could have wished my mistress too, and Erechtheus’ line, had been blest with children.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: My son, albeit the god hath for thy discovery brought his oracle

to a true issue, and united thee to me, while thou, too, hast found what most thou dost desire, till now unconscious of it; still, as touching this anxiety so proper in thee, I feel an equal yearning that thou, my child, mayst find thy mother, and I the wife that bare thee unto me.

Maybe we shall discover this, if we leave it to time. But now
leave the courts of the god, and this homeless life of thine, and come to Athens, in accordance with thy fathers wishes, for there his happy realm and bounteous wealth await thee; nor shalt thou

be taunted with base origin and poverty to boot, because in one of these respects thou something lackest, but thou shalt be renowned alike for birth and wealth. Art silent? why dost fix thy eyes upon the ground? Thou art lost in thought, and by this sudden change from thy former cheerfulness, thou strikest thy father with dismay.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Things assume a different form according as we see them before us, or far off. I am glad at what has happened, since I have found in thee a father; but hear me on some points which I am now deciding.

Athens, I am told,—that glorious city of a native race,—owns no aliens; in which case I shall force my entrance there under a twofold disadvantage, as an alien’s son and base-born as I am. Branded with this reproach, while as yet I am unsupported, I shall get the name of a mere nobody, a son of nobodies;

and if I win my way to the highest place in the state, and seek to be some one, I shall be hated by those who have no influence, for superiority is galling; while ’mongst men of worth who could show their wisdom, but are silent, and take no interest in politics,

I shall incur ridicule and be thought a fool for not keeping quiet in such a fault-finding city. Again, if I win a name amongst the men of mark who are engaged in politics, still more will jealous votes bar my progress; for thus, father, is it ever wont to be;
they who have the city’s ear, and have already made their mark, are most bitter against all rivals.

Again, if I, a stranger, come to a home that knows me not, and to that childless wife who before had
thee as partner in her sorrow, but now

will feel the bitterness of having to bear her fortune all alone,—how, I ask, shall I not fairly earn her hatred, when I take my stand beside thee; while she, still childless, sees thy dear pledge with bitter eyes; and then thou have to choose between deserting me and regarding her,

or honouring me and utterly confounding thy home? How many a murder, and death by deadly drugs have wives devised for husbands! Besides, I pity that wife of thine, father, with her childless old age beginning; she little deserves

to pine in barrenness, a daughter of a noble race. That princely state we fondly praise is pleasant to the eye; but yet in its mansions sorrow lurks; for who is happy, or by fortune blest, that has to live his life in fear of violence with many a sidelong glance?

Rather would I live among the common folk, and taste their bliss, than be a tyrant who delights in making evil men his friends, and hates the good, in terror of his life. Perchance thou wilt tell me, “Gold outweighs all these evils,

and wealth is sweet.” I have no wish to be abused for holding tightly to my pelf, nor yet to have the trouble of it. Be mine a moderate fortune free from annoyance! Now hear the blessings, father, that here were mine; first, leisure, man’s chiefest joy,

with but moderate trouble; no villain ever drove me from my path, and that is a grievance hard to bear, to make room and give way to sorry knaves. My duty was to pray unto the gods, or with mortal men converse, a minister to their joys, not to their Sorrows.

And I was ever dismissing one batch of guests, while another took their place, so that I was always welcome from the charm of novelty. That honesty which men must pray for, even against their will, custom and nature did conspire to plant in me in the sight of Phoebus. Now when
I think on this,
I deem that I am better here than there, father. So let me live on here, for ’tis an equal charm to joy in high estate, or in a humble fortune find a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Well said! if only those I love find their happiness in thy statement of the case.

sp.speaker: Xuthus
sp.l: Cease such idle talk, and learn to be happy; for on that spot where I discovered thee, my son, will I begin the rites, since I have chanced on the general banquet, open to all comers, and I will offer thy birth sacrifice which aforetime I left undone. And now will I bring thee to the banquet as my guest and rejoice thy heart,
and take thee to the Athenian land as a visitor forsooth, not as my own son. For I will not grieve my wife in her childless sorrow by my good fortune. But in time will I seize a happy moment

and prevail on her to let thee wield my sceptre o’er the realm. Thy name shall be Ion, in accordance with what happened, for that thou wert the first to cross my path as I came forth from Apollo’s sanctuary. Go, gather every friend thou hast, and with them make merry o’er the flesh of sacrifice,
on the eve of thy departure from the town of Delphi. On you, ye handmaids, silence I enjoin, for, if ye say one word to my wife, death awaits you.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Well, I will go; one thing my fortune lacks, for if I find not her that gave me birth, life is no life to me, my father;

and, if I may make the prayer, Oh may that mother be a daughter of Athens! that from-her I may inherit freedom of speech. For if a stranger settle in a city free from aliens, e’en though in name he be a citizen,
yet doth he find him-setf tongue-tied and debarred from open utterance.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l:
Weeping and lamentation and the beginning of
mourning I foresee, when my mistress shall see her lord blest with a son,
while she is childless and forlorn. What was this oracle thou didst vouchsafe, prophetic son of Latona? Whence came this boy, thy foster-child who lingers in thy temple? who was his mother?
I like not thy oracle; I fear there is some treachery. In terror I await the issue of this chance;
for strange are these tidings and strange it is that the god declares them to me. There is guile connected with this waif’s fortune. All must allow that.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Shall we, good friends, throw off disguise and tell our mistress this story about her husband in whom her all was centred and whose hopes, poor lady, she once shared? But now in misery is she plunged, while he enjoys the smiles of fortune;

to hoary eld she drifteth fast, while he, her lord, pays no regard to his loved ones,—the wretch, who came an alien to her house to share great wealth and failed to guard her fortunes! Perdition catch this traitor to my lady!
never may he succeed in offering to the gods upon their blazing altar a hallowed cake with flames that augur well! He shall know to his cost my regard
for my mistress. Now are sire and new-found son bent on the approaching feast.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ho! ye peaks of Parnassus
that rear your rocky heads to heaven, where Bacchus with uplifted torch of blazing pine bounds nimbly amid his bacchanals, that range by night! Never to my city come this boy!

let him die and leave his young life as it dawns! For should our city fall on evil days, this bringing-in of strangers would supply it with a reason. Enough, enough for us Erechtheus’ line that erst held sway!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Aged retainer of my father Erechtheus while yet he lived and saw the light of day, mount to the god’s prophetic shrine that thou mayst share my gladness, if haply Loxias, great king, vouchsafe an answer touching my hopes of offspring;

for sweet it is to share with friends prosperity, and sweet likewise to see a friendly face if any ill betide,—which God forbid! As thou of yore didst tend my sire, so now, thy mistress though I am, I take his place in tending thee.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Daughter, thy manners bear good witness still to thy noble lineage; thou hast never brought shame upon those ancestors of thine, the children of the soil. A hand, I prithee, to the shrine! a hand to lean upon!’Tis a steep path thither, truly;
but lend thy aid to guide my steps and make me young again.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Come follow then, and look where thou art treading.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Behold! though my steps loiter, my thoughts take wings.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Lean on thy staff as thou climbest this winding path.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Even this staff is a blind guide when I myself can scarcely see.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: True, but do not yield through fatigue.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Never willingly, but I am not master of that which is mine no more.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Maidens mine, my trusty servants at the loom and web, declare to me how my lord hath fared as touching the question of offspring which brought us hither:
for if ye give me good news, ye will cause joy to a mistress who will not prove faithless to her word.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: O fortune!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: This prelude to your speech is unlucky.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Woe is me!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Can it be that the oracles delivered to my master wound me at all?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Enough! why have aught to do with that which brings down death?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What means this piteous strain? wherefore this alarm?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Are we to speak or keep silence? What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Speak; for thou hast somewhat to tell that touches me.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Then speak I will, though twice to die were mine. O mistress mine! never shalt thou hold a babe within thy arms or clasp him to thy breast.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah me! would I were dead!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: My daughter!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: O woe is me for my calamity! Mine is a heritage of suffering and woe that poisons life, good friends.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Ah, my child, ’tis death to us!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah me! ah me! grief drives its weapon through this heart of mine.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Stay thy lamentations.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Nay, but sorrow lodges here.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Till we learn—

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah, what further news is there for me?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Whether our master is in the same plight and shares thy misfortune, or thou art alone in thy misery.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: On him, old sir, Loxias hath bestowed a son,
and he is enjoying his good fortune apart from her.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Herein hast thou declared a further evil crowning all, a grief for me to mourn.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: The child of whom thou speakest—is he some woman’s destined babe, or did the god declare the fate of one already born?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: A youth already born and grown to man’s estate doth Phoebus give to him; for I was there myself.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What sayest thou? nor tongue nor lip should speak the word thou tellest me.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: And me. But declare more clearly how this oracle is finding its fulfilment, and say who is the child.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Whomso thy husband first should meet as he issued from the shrine, him the god gave him for his son.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah me! my fate, it seems, has doomed me to a childless
life, and all forlorn am I to dwell in ray halls, without an heir.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: To whom did the oracle refer? whom did our poor lady’s husband meet? how and where did he see him?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Dear mistress mine, dost know that youth
that was sweeping yonder shrine? He is that son.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Oh! for wings to cleave the liquid air beyond the land of Hellas, away to the western stars, so keen the anguish of my soul, my friends!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Dost know the name his father gave to him, or is that left as yet unsettled and unsaid?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: He called him Ion, because he was the first to cross his path.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Who is his mother?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: That I cannot say. But,—to tell thee all I know, old sir,—

her lord is gone, with furtive step, into the hallowed tent, there to offer on this child’s behalf such gifts and victims as are offered for a birth, and with his new-found son to celebrate the feast.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Mistress mine, we are betrayed by thy husband, fellow-sufferers thou and I; ’tis a deep-laid plot to outrage us

and drive us from Erechtheus’ halls. And this I say not from any hatred of thy lord but because I bear thee more love than him; for he, after coming as a stranger to thy city and thy home, and wedding thee, and of thy heritage taking full possession,

has been detected in a secret marriage with another woman, by whom he hath children. His secret will I now disclose; when he found thee barren, he was not content to share with thee thy hard
lot, but took to himself a slave to be his stealthy paramour

and thus begat a son, whom he sent abroad, giving him to some Delphian maid to nurse; and, to escape detection, the child was dedicated to the god and reared in his temple. But when he heard his boy was grown to manhood, he persuaded thee to come hither to inquire about thy childless state.

And after this, ’twas not the god that lied, but thy husband, who long had been rearing the child, and he it was that wove this tissue of falsehood, intending, if he were detected, to refer it to the god, whereas if he escaped exposure, to repel all odium, he meant to vest the sovereignty in this son of his.
Likewise he devised anew his name, coined to suit the circumstances, Ion, because, as he asserts, he met him on his way.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ah! how I ever hate the wicked
who plot unrighteousness and then cunningly trick it out. Far rather would I have a virtuous friend of no great intellect than a knave of subtler wit.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Of all thy wretched fate this will be the crowning sorrow, the bringing to thy house to be its lord some slave-girl’s child, whose mother is unknown, himself of no account. For this evil had been to itself confined,

had he persuaded thee, pleading thy childlessness, to let him establish in the house some high-born mother’s son; or if this had displeased thee, he ought to have sought a daughter of Aeolus in marriage. Wherefore must thou now put thy woman’s wit to work; either take the dagger, or by guile

or
poison slay thy husband and his son, ere they deal out death to thee; since if thou spare him, thou wilt lose thy own life; for when two foes meet beneath one roof, one or the other must rue it.

Myself too am ready to share this labour with thee, and to help destroy the child when I have made my way into the chamber where he is furnishing the feast, and so repaying my masters for my maintenance I am willing either to die or still behold the light of life. ’Tis but a single thing that brands the slave with shame—
his name; in all else no upright slave is a whit worse than freeborn men.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: I too, beloved mistress, am ready to share thy fate, be it death or victory.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah! my suffering soul! how am I to keep silence?
Am I to disclose the secrets of my love and lose all claim to modesty? What is there to keep me back any longer? With whom have I to pit myself in virtue’s lists? Hath not my husband proved untrue?
Home and children, both are torn from me; all hope is dead; I have not realized my wish to set the matter straight, by hushing up my former union and saying naught about my son of sorrow.
No! by the starry seat of Zeus, by her whose home is on my rocks, and by the hallowed strand of Triton’s mere with brimming flood, I will no more conceal my love; for if

I can lift that burden from my breast I shall rest easier. With tears my eyes are streaming and my heart is wrung with anguish for the treacherous counsels both of men and gods,—traitors they! as I will show,
ungrateful traitors to their loves!
O! thou who dost awake that tuneful lyre with seven strings till to its sweet note of music the lifeless pegs of wild ox-hom resound again,
thou child of Latona, to yon 293 bright orb of thine will I publish thy reproach. Yes, I saw thee come, the glint of gold upon thy locks, as I was gathering in my folded robe the saffron blooms
that blazed like flowers of gold; and by my lily wrist didst thou catch me and ledst me to the cavern’s bed, what time I cried aloud upon my mother’s name,—thou a god
to mate with me in shameless wise to pleasure lady Cypris! Then to my sorrow I bore thee a son, whom, though anguish thrilled my mother’s breast, I cast upon that bed of thine,
where thou didst join in woful wedlock this unhappy maid. Ah! woe is me! that poor babe I bare thee is now no more; winged fowls have tom and devoured him,
but thou art gaily carolling unto thy lyre some song of joy.
Hark! thou son of Latona, to thee I call, for that thou dispensest warnings; there at thy golden throne
on earth’s centre planted will I proclaim a word into thy ear. O! thou wicked bridegroom who art bringing to my husband’s house an heir, though from him thou hast received no boon;
while that child of thine and mine hath died unrecognized, a prey to carrion birds, his mother’s swaddling-clothes all lost. Delos hates thee now, thy bay-tree loves thee not,
whose branches sprout beside the tufted palm, where in holy throes Latona, big with child by Zeus, gave birth to thee.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ah me! what store of sorrows is here disclosed, enough to draw a tear from every eye!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Daughter, with pity am I filled as a gaze upon thy face; my reason leaves me; for just as I am striving to lighten my spirit of its sea of troubles, comes another wave astern and catches me by reason of thy words; for no sooner hadst thou uttered this tale of present troubles

than thou didst turn aside into a fresh a track of other woes. What is it thou sayest? What charge against Apollo dost thou
bring? What child is this thou dost assert that thou didst bear? Where was it in the city that thou didst expose him, for beasts to rejoice o’er his burial? Tell me once again.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Old friend, although to meet thine eye, I am ashamed, yet will I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Full well I know how to lend my friends a generous sympathy.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Then hearken; dost know a cave toward the north of Cecrops’ rock, that we call Macrae?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: I know it; there is the shrine of Pan, and his altar hard by.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: That was the scene of my dire conflict.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: What conflict? see how my tears start forth to meet thy words.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Phoebus forced me to a woful marriage.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Was it then this, my daughter, that I noticed myself?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I know not; but I will tell thee if thou speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: At the time thou wert mourning in secret some hidden complaint?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yes, ’twas then this trouble happened, which now I am declaring to thee.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: How then didst conceal thy union with Apollo?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I bore a child; hear me patiently, old friend.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Where? and who helped thy travail? or didst thou labour all alone?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: All alone, in the cave where I became a wife.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Where is the child? that thou mayst cease thy childless state.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Dead, old friend, to beasts exposed.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Dead? did Apollo, evil god, no help afford?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: None; my boy is in the halls of Hades.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Who then exposed him? surely not thyself.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Myself, when ’neath the gloom of night I had wrapped him in my robe.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Did no one share thy secret of the babe’s exposure?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ill-fortune and secrecy alone.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: How couldst thou in the cavern leave thy babe?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ah! how? but still I did, with many a word of pity uttered o’er him.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Oh for thy hard heart! Oh for the god’s, more hard than thine!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Hadst thou but seen the babe stretch forth his hands to me!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: To find thy mother’s breast, to nestle in thy arms?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: By being kept therefrom he suffered grievous wrong from me.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: How earnest thou to think of casting forth thy babe?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Methought the god would save his own begotten child.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Ah me! what storms assail thy family’s prosperity!

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Why weepest thou, old man, with head close-veiled?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: To see the sorrows of thy sire and thee.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Such is our mortal life; naught abideth in one stay.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Daughter, let us cease to dwell on themes of woe.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What must I do? Misfortune leaves us helpless.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Avenge thee on the god who first did injure thee.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: How can I, weak mortal as I am, outrun those mightier powers?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Set fire to Apollo’s awful sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I am afraid; my present sorrows are enough for me.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Then what thou canst, that dare—thy husband’s death.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Nay, I do respect his former love in the days when he was good and true.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: At least, then, slay the boy who hath appeared to supplant thee.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: How can I? would it were possible! how I wish it were!

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Arm thy followers with daggers.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I will about it; but where is the deed to be done?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: In the sacred tent, where he is feasting his friends.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: The murder will be too public, and slaves are poor support.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Ah! thou art turning coward. Devise some scheme thyself.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Well, I too have subtle plans that cannot fail.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: If both conditions they fulfil, I will assist thee.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Hearken then; knowest thou the battle of the earth-born men?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Surely; the fight at Phlegra waged by giants against the gods.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: There Earth brought Gorgon forth, dreadful prodigy.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: To aid her sons maybe, and cause the gods hard toil?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yea, and Pallas, daughter of Zeus, slew the monster.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: What savage form had it assumed?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: A breast-plate of vipers fenced its body.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Is this the tale I heard in days of yore?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: That Athena wears its skin upon her corslet.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Is it this that Pallas wears, called by men her aegis?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: This was the name it received, that day she came to do battle for the gods.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: How, daughter, can this harm thy enemies?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Hast heard of Erichthonius, or no? of course thou hast.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Him whom Earth produced, the founder of thy race?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: To him whilst yet a babe did Pallas give—

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Ha! what? thou hast something yet to add?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Two drops of Gorgon’s blood.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: What power could they exert on the nature of a human creature?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: The one with death is fraught, the other cures disease.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: What held them when she tied them to the child’s body?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: With links of gold she fastened them; this to my sire did Erichthonius give.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: And at his death it came to thee?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yea, and here at my wrist I wear it.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: How works the spell of this double gift of Pallas?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Each drop of gore which trickled from the hollow vein—

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: What purpose does it serve? what virtue does it carry?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Wards off disease, and nourishes man’s life.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: What doth that second drop effect, of which thou madest mention?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: It kills, for it is venom from the Gorgon’s snakes.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Dost thou carry this charm mixed in one phial, or separate?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Separate; for good is no companion for evil.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Daughter dear, thou art fully armed with all thou needest.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: By this must the boy die, and thou must do the deadly deed.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: How and where? thine it is to speak, and mine to dare and do.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: In Athens, when to my house he comes.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: That is not wisely said; I may object to thy plan as thou to mine.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: How so? Hast thou the same mistrust that I experience?

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Thou wilt get the credit of his death, although thou slay him not.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: True; men say stepdames are jealous of their husband’s children.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Kill him here then, that so thou mayst deny the murder.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Well, thus I do anticipate the pleasure.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Yea, and thou wilt from thy husband keep the very secret he would keep from thee.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Dost know then what to do? Take from my arm

this golden bracelet, Athena’s gift, some ancient craftsman’s work, and seek the spot where my lord is offering secret sacrifice; then when their feasting is o’er and they are about to pour drink-offering to the gods, take this phial in thy robe and pour it into the young man’s goblet;

not for all, but for him alone, providing a separate draught, who thinks to lord it o’er my house. And if once it pass his lips, never shall he come to glorious Athens, but here abide, of life bereft.

sp.speaker: Old Servant
sp.l: Go thou within the house of our public hosts;

I the while will set about my appointed task. On! aged foot, grow young again in action, for all that time saith no to thee. Go, aid thy mistress against her enemy, help slay
and drag him from her house.
’Tis well to honour piety in the hour of fortune, but when thou wouldst harm thy foe, no law doth block thy path.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Daughter of Demeter, goddess of highways, queen as thou art of haunting powers of darkness,
oh! guide as well the hand that fills by day a cup of death, against those to whom my revered mistress is sending a philtre of the gore that dripped from hellish Gorgon’s severed head,
yea, ’gainst him who would obtrude upon the halls of the Erechthidae. Never may alien, from alien stock, lord it o’er my city,
no! none save noble Erechtheus’ sons!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: For if this deadly deed and my lady’s aims pass unfulfilled, and the right moment for her daring go by, and with it the hope which now sustains her, either will she seize the whetted knife
or fasten the noose about her neck, and by ending one sorrow by another will go down to other phases of existence. For never will that daughter of a noble line,
while life is hers, endure within the sunshine of her eyes the sight of alien rulers in her halls.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: I blush for that god of song,
if this stranger is to witness the torch-dance, that heralds in the twentieth dawn, around Callichorus’ fair springs, a sleepless votary in midnight revels, what time the star-lit firmament of Zeus,
the moon, and Nereus’ fifty daughters, that trip it lightly o’er the sea and the eternal rivers’ tides, join the dance in honour
of the maiden with the crown of gold and her majestic mother; where this vagabond, by Phoebus favoured, thinks to reign, entering into other men’s hard toil.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Look to it, all ye bards, who, in malicious strains, expose our amours and unholy bonds of lawless love; see how far our

virtue surpasses man’s
disloyalty. Change the burden of your song and keep your spiteful verse to brand man’s faithlessness. For this scion of the stock of Zeus
shows himself a heedless wight, denying to the mistress of his halls the lot of mutual offspring, and, paying all his court to some strange love,
hath gotten him a bastard son.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Ladies of another land, where may I find your mistress, daughter of Erechtheus? For I have searched each nook and corner of this town, and cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: What news, my fellow-thrall? why that hurried gait? what tidings bringest thou?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I am pursued; the rulers of this land are seeking her to stone her to death.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Alas, what is thy tale? say not we are detected in our secret plot for murdering the boy?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Thou hast guessed aright; nor wilt thou be the last to share the trouble.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: How was the hidden scheme laid bare?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The god found means to master wrong with right, unwilling to see his shrine polluted.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: How so? I do conjure thee, tell us all.
For if to die or yet to live be ours, ’twere sweeter so, when we know all.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Soon as Xuthus, husband of Creusa, had left the god’s prophetic shrine, taking with him his new-found son, to hold the feast and sacrifice that he designed to offer to the gods,

himself departed to the place where leaps the Bacchic flame, with blood of sacrifice to dew the double peaks of Dionysus for the son now offered to his gaze, and thus he spake, My son, abide thou here, and raise a spacious tent by craftsmen’s toiling skill;

l.q: and if I remain long time away after I have sacrificed to the gods of thy birth, let the feast be spread for all friends present.

sp.l:
Therewith he took the heifers and went his way. Meantime his stripling son in solemn form set up with upright stays the tent, inclosed but not
with walls,

taking good heed to guard it ’gainst the blazing midday sun, nor less against his westering beams, the limit of his course; an oblong space of five score feet he meted out so that it contained ten thousand feet within that measure’s square, as science phrases it,

intending to invite all Delphi to the feast. Then from the temple-treasury tapestry he took and therewith made a shelter, wondrous sight to see. First o’er the roof-tree he threw a canopy of robes, an offering Heracles, the son of Zeus,

had brought unto the god from his Amazonian spoils. On them was broidered many a pictured scene, to wit, Heaven marshalling his host of stars upon the vaulted sky; there was the sun-god urging on his steeds toward his fiery goal, the bright star of evening at his heels.

Night too in sable robes went hurrying by, drawn by a single pair, and the stars did bear her company. Across the zenith a Pleiad sailed, and Orion too with falchion dight was there; above was the bear making his tail to turn upon the golden pole.

Up shot the moon’s full face, that parts the months in twain; there too the Hyades showed their unerring light to mariners; arid Dawn, that brings the morning back, was chasing the stars before her. Next on the sides he hung yet other tapestry;

barbarian ships bearing down on the fleet of Hellas; and monsters half-man, half-beast; the capture of the Thracian steeds; the hunting of savage stags and lions fierce; while at the entry Cecrops close to his daughters was wreathing his coils, an offering of some Athenian

votary; and in the midst of the banquet-hall he set goblets of gold, while a herald hasted and invited to the feast all citizens who would come. Then, when the tent was full, they decked themselves with garlands and took their fill

of the rich viands. Anon after they had put from them the pleasure of eating came an old
man and stood in the midst, where his officious zeal provoked loud laughter among the guests; for he would draw from the drinking-pitchers water to wash the hands withal and
was wasting as incense the liquid myrrh, and in his charge he took the golden beakers, setting himself unasked to this office.
Now when they were come to the time for the flute-players and the general libation, cried out that aged servitor, “Hence with these tiny cups! bring larger goblets,

that our guests may find a quicker route to joyousness.” Thereon came servants bending ’neath the weight of goblets chased with silver and golden chalices; and that old man, as if to do his youthful lord a special service, chose out and offered to him a brimming bumper, when he had cast into the wine

that potent philtre which, men say, his mistress gave to him to end the young man’s days on earth; and no man knew of this; but just as he so lately found held in his hand the drink-offering, the others following suit, some servant there uttered a word of evil import;

whereat the stripling, as one who had been reared within the shrine amid reputed seers, deemed this an omen and bade them fill a fresh goblet, but that first drink-offering to the god he poured upon the ground and bade all others do the like. And silence stole upon them;

while we with water and Phoenician wine were filling high the sacred bowls. While thus we were busied, comes a flight of doves and settles in the tent, for these dwell fearlessly in the courts of Loxias. Soon as the guests had poured away the luscious juice, those thirsty birds did dip their beaks therein,
drawing it up into their feathered throats.

Now all the rest received no hurt from the god’s libation, but one that settled on the spot where the son newfound had poured his wine, no sooner had tasted thereof,
than convulsions seized her feathered form and she went triad, and screaming aloud uttered
strange unwonted cries; and all the feasters gathered there marvelled to see the bird’s cruel agony, for she lay writhing in the toils of death, and her red claws relaxed their hold.
Forthwith the son, vouchsafed by oracles, bared his arm by casting off his cloak and stretched it out across the board

crying Who was it strove to slay me? Proclaim it, old sirrah, for thine was the officious zeal and thine the hand from which I took the cup. With that he caught the grey-beard by the arm and set to searching him that he might take the old man red-handed in the act.

So was he detected, and under strong constraint declared Creusa’s daring deed and all the trick of the poisoned draught. Forth rushed the young man, whom the oracle of Loxias to his sire assigned, taking with him the banqueters, and standing mid the Delphic nobles made harangue,

O! hallowed soil, a stranger woman, daughter of Erechtheus, seeks to poison me. And the lords of Delphi decreed by general vote that my mistress should be hurled from the rock to die, because she strove to slay the priest and compass his death in the temple.
So now is the whole city seeking her, who hath to her sorrow sped a hapless journey; for, coming to crave the boon of offspring from Phoebus, she hath lost her life and children too.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ah me! I see no way at all to turn death’s
hand aside; all, all, ere this, is brought to light owing to that fatal draught of the wine-god’s juice mixed for death with drops of viper’s gore, quick to slay;

detected is our offering to the dead; for me my life must end in woe, while death by stoning waits my mistress. How can I escape? Shall I take wings and fly away, or creep beneath the darksome caverns of the earth,
striving to shun the doom of death by stoning? or shall I mount the car drawn by swiftest steeds, or embark upon a ship?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: No man may hide his guilt, save when some

god of his own will steals him away. Ah! my
poor mistress! what suffering now awaits thy soul? Must then our wish to work another harm end in our own discomfiture, as justice doth decree?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: My trusty maids, the men of death are on my track; the vote of Delphi goes against me; they give me up to die.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Unhappy one! we know thy sad mischance, how thou art placed.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Oh! whither can I fly? for scarce had I the start of my pursuers from the house in my race for life; ’tis by stealth alone that I have thus far escaped my foes.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Where shouldst thou fly except to the altar?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: What good is that to me?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: To slay a suppliant is forbidden.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Aye, but the law has given me over to death.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Only if thou fall into their hands.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Look! here they come, cruel champions of vengeance, eagerly brandishing their swords.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Sit thee down upon the altar of burnt-offering! for if thou art slain there, thou wilt fix
upon thy murderers the stain of bloodguiltiness; but we must bear our fortune.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: O father Cephissus, with the bull-shaped head, what a viper is this thy child, or dragon with fiery eyes that dart a murderous gleam, in whose heart is throned incarnate daring,

noxious as those Gorgon drops of venom wherewith she sought to compass my death. Seize her, that the peaks of Parnassus may card the flowing tresses of her hair, for thence shall she be hurled headlong amid the rocks. My lucky star hath kept me

from going to Athens, there to fall beneath the power of a step-mother. For I have gauged thy feelings towards me—the full extent of thy bitter hostility—whilst yet amongst my friends; for hadst thou once shut me
tip within thy house, my road to Hades’ halls had led direct from thence.
This altar shall not save thee, nor yet Apollo’s courts, for that pity thou implorest cries out more loudly for me and my mother, who, though absent in the flesh, is never in name far from me.
Behold this cursed woman, see the web of trickery she hath woven! yet comes she cowering to Apollo’s altar, thinking to escape the punishment of her misdeeds.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I warn thee not to slay me, both in my own name and in his at whose altar I am stationed.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What hast thou to do with Phoebus?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: This body I devote unto that god to keep.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: And yet thou wert for poisoning his minister?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: But thou wert not Apollo’s any longer, but thy father’s.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Nay, I was his son, that is, in absence of a real father.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Thou wert so then; now ’tis I, not thou, who am Apollo’s.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Well, thou art not guiltless now, whereas I was then.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: I sought to slay thee as an enemy to my house.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: And yet I never invaded thy country, sword in hand.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Thou didst; and thou it was that wert casting a firebrand into the halls of Erechtheus.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What sort of brand or flaming fire was it?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Thou didst design to seize my home against my will, and make it thine.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What! when my father offered me a kingdom of his getting.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: How had the sons of Aeolus any share in the realm of Pallas?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Arms, not words, he brought to champion it.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: No mere ally could enter into an inheritance in my land.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: And was it then from fear of consequences that thou didst try to slay me?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Yes, lest I should myself perish if thou wert spared.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Doth thy childlessness make thee envious that my father found me?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: And thou, wilt thou rob the childless of her home?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Had I then no share at all in my father’s heritage?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: All that his sword and shield had won was thine, and thine alone.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Quit the altar and sanctuary built for gods.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Go bid thy own mother, wherever she is, do that.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Shalt thou escape all punishment, after trying to kill me?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Not if thou choose to butcher me within this shrine.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What joy can it give thee to be slain amid the sacred wreaths?

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: There is one whom I shall grieve of those who have grieved me.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Oh! ’tis passing strange how badly the deity hath enacted laws for mortal men, contrary to all sound judgment; for instance, they should ne’er have suffered impious men to sit at their altars,

but should have driven them away; for it was nowise right that hands unclean should touch the altars of the gods, though the righteous deserved to find a refuge there from their oppressors, instead of good and bad alike having recourse to the same divine protection with equal success.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Refrain thyself, my son; for I, the priestess of Phoebus, chosen from all the maids of Delphi in accordance with the tripod’s ancient rite, have left that prophetic seat, and am passing o’er this threshold.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hail to thee, dear mother mine,—mother, though thou didst not give me birth.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Yes, so have I ever been called, and the title causes me no regret.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hast heard how this woman plotted my death?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: I have; thou, too, art wrong because of thy harshness.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Am I not to pay back murderers in their coin?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Wives ever hate the children of a former marriage.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: As I hate step-dames for their evil treatment of me.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Do not so; but leaving, as thou art, the shrine, and setting forth for thy country—

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What then wouldst thou advise me do?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: With clean hands seek Athens, attended by good omens.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Surely any man hath clean hands who slays his enemies.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Do not thou do this; but take the counsel that I have for thee.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Say on; whate’er thou say’st will be prompted by thy good will.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Dost see this basket that I carry in my arms?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: An ancient ark with chaplets crowned.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Herein I found thee long ago, a newborn babe.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What sayest thou? there is novelty in the story thou art introducing.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Yea, for I was keeping these relics a secret, but now I show them.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: How earnest thou to hide them on that day, now long ago, when thou didst find me?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: The god wished to have thee as his servant in his courts.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Does he no longer wish it? How am I to know this?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: By declaring to thee thy sire, he dismisses thee from this land.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Is it by his command thou keepest these relics, or why?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Loxias put in my heart that day—

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What purpose? Oh! speak, finish thy story.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: To preserve what I had found until the present time.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: What weal or woe doth this import to me?

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Herein were laid the swaddling-clothes in which thou wert enwrapped.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: These relics thou art producing may help me to find my mother.

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Yes, for now the deity so wills it, though not before.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Hail! thou day of visions blest to me!

sp.speaker: Pythian Priestess
sp.l: Take then the relics and seek thy mother diligently.
This line is assigned to Ion in the Greek.And when thou hast traversed Asia and the bounds of Europe,
thou wilt learn this for thyself; for the god’s sake I reared thee, my child, and now to thee do I entrust these relics, which he willed that I should take

into my safe keeping, without being bidden; why he willed it I cannot tell thee. For no living soul wist that I had them in my possession, nor yet their hiding-place. And now farewell! as a mother might her child, so I greet thee. The starting-point of thy inquiry for thy mother must be this;

first, was it a Delphian maid that gave birth to thee, and exposed thee in this temple; next, was it a daughter of Hellas at all? That is all that I and Phoebus, who shares in thy lot, can do for thee. [Exit Pythian Priestess.

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Ah me! the tears stream from my eyes

when I think of the day my mother bore me, as the fruit of her secret love, only to smuggle her babe away privily, without suckling it; nameless I led a servant’s life in the courts of the god. His service truly was kindly, yet was my fortune

heavy; for just when I ought to have lain softly in a mother’s arms, tasting somewhat of the joys of life, was I deprived of a fond mother’s fostering care. Nor less is she a prey to sorrow that bare me, seeing she hath suffered the self-same pang in losing all the joy a son might bring.

Now will I take and bear this ark unto the god as an offering, that herein I may discover naught that I would rather not. For if haply my mother proves to be some slave-girl, ’twere worse to find her out than let her rest in silence. O! Phoebus, to thy temple do I dedicate this ark.

Yet why? this is to war against the god’s intention, who saved these tokens of my mother for my sake. I must undo the lid and bear the worst. For that which fate ordains, I may ne’er o’erstep. O! hallowed wreaths and fastenings,

that have kept so safe these relics dear to me; why, ah! why were ye hidden from me? Behold the covering of this rounded ark! No signs of age are here, owing to some miracle; decay hath not touched these chaplets; and yet ’tis long enough since these were stored away.

sp.speaker: Creusa
sp.l: Ha! what unlooked-for sight is here?

sp.speaker: Ion
sp.l: Peace, woman! now, as erst, thou art my enemy.

sp.speaker: Creusa
